title.value: Stimulus information guides the emergence of behavior-related signals in primary somatosensory cortex during learning
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly stated at the beginning of the document and in the header of certain sections.
title.quote:
Stimulus information guides the emergence of
behavior-related signals in primary somatosensory
cortex during learning

extractions.description: The paper studies how sensory and behavior-related information emerge and are integrated in the primary somatosensory cortex of mice during a learning task. It uses in vivo imaging techniques to observe neuronal activity changes in response to sensory learning.

type.justification: The paper is based on experiments conducted on mice to observe changes in neuronal activity during learning.
type.quote: We investigated this question by imaging neuronal activity in mouse primary somatosensory cortex before, during, and after learning of an object localization task.

name.justification: The study involves observing neuronal activity in the brain related to sensory and behavioral signals during learning, indicating its focus on neuroscience.
name.quote:
Neurons in the primary cortex carry sensory- and behavior-related information, but it remains an open ques-
tion how this information emerges and intersects together during learning.

name.justification: The paper uses neuroimaging techniques such as two-photon calcium imaging to monitor neuronal activity.
name.quote: We trained mice on a head-fixed tactile object localization task, using two-photon imaging to longitudinally record the activity of excitatory neurons.

name.justification: The paper explores how sensory information is processed and integrated with behavioral responses in the primary somatosensory cortex.
name.quote:
Neuronal activity in the vibrissal primary somatosensory cortex
(vS1) of mice successfully trained on a sensory task reflects
not only sensory stimuli but also various types of behavior-
related information.

name.justification: Linear Regression Models were used to decode stimulus and choice from neural activity.
name.quote:
Calculating MI on the activity of increasing numbers of in-
dividual neurons is subject to a systematic bias due to the limited
number of experimental trials available. Therefore, following
established machine learning practices, we estimated the MI
for groups of neurons using the MI computed on the confusion
matrices obtained by training linear regression models to
decode stimulus (decMI(R;S)) or choice (decMI(R;C)) from neural
activity.

is_contributed.justification: The models used are linear regression models, which are well-established and not newly contributed by the paper.
